title: 5 Essential Grip Tools Every Photographer Should Know
summary: Professional photographer Lindsay Adler introduces five fundamental pieces of grip equipment essential for studio photography and assisting. She explains the function, industry terminology, and practical applications for each tool to improve set safety and efficiency.

steps.action: Use A Clamps (spring-loaded clamps) to secure backgrounds, gels, cables, or to adjust the fit of clothing on a model.
Utilize a Cardellini Clamp (or Matthellini) to grip onto flat or round surfaces like pipes and table edges. Use it to hold bounce cards, scrims, or mount lights in unusual places.
Deploy Apple Boxes for standing, sitting, or propping up gear. Use the specific orientations: 'New York' (tallest), 'Chicago' (medium side), and 'L.A.' (flat/lowest).
Set up a Knuckle (Grip Head) on a C-Stand arm to hold flags, scrims, or lights. Ensure the weight is on the 'righty-tighty' side so gravity tightens the knuckle rather than loosening it.
Use a Super Clamp with accessories like J-Hooks (for hanging packs or background poles) or Pins (for mounting lights) to create setups like lighting trees.

key_takeaways: Grip equipment is essential for safety, efficiency, and professionalism on set.
Apple boxes have specific names for their orientations: New York (tallest), Chicago (side), and L.A. (flat).
When using a Knuckle/Grip Head, always position the weight so that gravity tightens the handle ('Righty Tighty' rule) to prevent equipment damage.
Super Clamps are versatile due to accessories like J-Hooks and Pins, allowing for complex rigging like lighting trees.
